schedule.title: Developing AI Proficiency Throughout Africa: Who We Aspire to Be
schedule.speaker: Kayode Oladapo
schedule.description:
The talk "Developing AI Proficiency Throughout Africa: Who We Aspire to Be" is to present the meaningful, informed, and beneficial participation of AI development, proficiency, and utilization within the African communities. The audience for this talk includes developers, data analysts, and everyone interested in the story of African communities in AI and dataset collection in Africa. 
Attendees can expect to gain an understanding of how the "global AI war" is not about technology, the reshaping of global power, fostering technological decoupling, and demanding African attention. They will understand the stakes of Africa and the aspiration to avoid digital colonialism and ensure African proficiency and participation is truly meaningful. By the end of the talk, attendees will have a grasp of how stakeholders in Africa are shaping AI decisions, fostering a deep understanding of its implications, and the commitment to AI proficiency that genuinely advances African societal well-being, equity promotion, and championing inclusivity across all sectors. 
The talk will cover a range of topics, including
1. Who truly owns Africa's AI future?
2. Prevention of digital colonialism when AI is trained on non-African data.
3. Building competitive AI talent for proficiency.
This talk will equip all attendees at various stages of experience with how Africans at the moment are aspiring, deliberate, decisive, and determined in shaping our AI proficiency and destiny in building an AI future that truly benefits all African communities.

schedule.title: Breaking educational barriers for pupils with dyslexia using python in underdeveloped countries
schedule.speaker: Jacobs Oluwakemi
schedule.description:
In underdeveloped countries, getting an inclusive education is still quite difficult, especially for kids with learning difficulties like dyslexia. Imprecise word comprehension and generally subpar reading performance are hallmarks of dyslexia, a neurological disease. It impacts a sizable portion of school-age children, with a higher prevalence in boys, putting them at lifetime risk for subpar academic achievement and low self-esteem.
The United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) believes that between 10% and 20% of people worldwide suffer with dyslexia, indicating that the disorder is highly prevalent. It might potentially be as high as 30% in low-income areas.
In traditional educational institutions, children with dyslexia frequently encounter obstacles that restrict their exposure to critical skills like programming, which are vital in the digital age. IT skills are a crucial tool to support dyslexic pupils because they can help them learn and reduce difficulties with identifying or confusing words and meaning. Several studies have demonstrated the importance of exposing students to IT skills, such as programming, especially those with special learning difficulties. Pupils with dyslexia typically have low expectations for their academic opportunities and low self-esteem. 

This talk examines how Python's ease of use and adaptability might be utilized to produce educational materials and programming tools that are accessible to dyslexic kids in underdeveloped countries. Interactive, multi-sensory learning tools can be created using Python libraries such as Turtle, Pyttsx3 and Pygame for auditory and visuals thus creating engagement for dyslexic kids and lowering pressure on cognitive skills. These resources are perfect for countries with limited resources because they require less infrastructure for technology. 
Join us as we explore python for inclusive education and creating a new generation of pupils who are masters of digital skills regardless of their situation and showing that coding is for everyone, breaking barriers and giving equal opportunities to dyslexic kids.
